abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings show a satisfactory
            outcome, highly likely sustainability, substantial
            institutional development impacts, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Project and
            program-related Lessons outline inter-agency cooperation at
            border cross points, where a cooperative culture should be
            encouraged and promoted top down by the management of
            regulatory agencies, making changes in procedures at border
            crossing points as needed in the future. It is suggested
            that frequent rotation of staff in the Customs Directorate
            be avoided, to ensure smooth project implementation, and
            that Customs control remain under efficient selective
            procedure. Bank-related Lessons suggest focusing not only on
            trade facilitation, but on legitimate security requirements,
            and anti-terrorism aspects, such as a container security
            code for scanning of cargoes. Further, the Bank should
            recognize that, when the project involves several innovative
            reforms, it is expected to have higher risks, but higher
            rewards as well. Main characteristics of the project were
            that it was result oriented, with measurable indicators, a
            unique quality and a major factor which contributed to the
            success of the project, as well as policy dialogues and
            cooperation among several border agencies, which deepened
            the project success. In addition, the regional approach,
            better results are achieved as opposed to a stand-alone
            project, for it creates peer pressure among the
            participating countries, in turn, generates competitiveness
            and motivation for improved performance. Finally, the
            contribution of the United States as a parallel financier
            contributed to the success of the project: the USAID Grant
            was instrumental in improving public-private partnership,
            especially in light of the Government's reluctancy to
            borrow for technical assistance to the private sector.
